@junrao @fpj Could you also help take a look at this patch. I basically extended from org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient. I am trying to be less intrusive in this patch so we can still leverage the useful functions in org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient . As of now it seems sufficient to solve our problem in KAFKA-3083. 

Gradually we can add more things to the kafka.utils.ZkClient. Eventually it can be based on ZooKeeper native client and replace org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.

The fix here keeps the autocommit task running regardless of the subscription/assignment state. Before we were trying to start it and stop it depending on whether the group had been joined, but that clearly doesn't work when partitions are assigned manually.
It looks like checking coverage actually runs the tests. Is this expected?
@hachikuji Can you take a pass at this, keeping in mind compatibility issues by adding new API? We'll need a KIP here too, but we might as well get the patch in shape before proceeding with that.
I think so. The reason is that the tests must run after the code is instrumented so that coverage can be recorded.
It is the only place where we have a log sentence like this. So I just changed from info to warn.
@harshach Since you previously reviewed this and I addressed your comment, would you be able to take a look again?

@gwenshap Yeah, I think this is expected. It doesn't, however, seem to obey the same parallelism as normal tests. Unfortunate, but hopefully fixable in a follow up. I previously started to review this and then got sidetracked as the test run took about 40 minutes to execute :)

Overall, I'm +1 on this pretty non-risky patch that makes an awesome incremental step towards Kafka actually paying attention to test coverage. Left one question, but otherwise LGTM

+1 as well. I like the report :)

I was a bit concerned by the time it took, but looks like this is inevitable.

@ewencp @gwenshap Yeah the java runs aren't as bad, and if you like you can run a report on just the modules you care about. The Scala coverage report definitely takes a while. Thats why I have made this an optional task to start. Hopefully we can speed this up in the future. Speeding up core tests in general would be nice too.
@ewencp @gwenshap Removed the extraneous jcenter() line

@becketqin : In KAFKA-3083, we discussed that we probably need to have access to the raw zk client to handle the ZK session expiration events correctly. There are other jiras in KAFKA-3210 that can also benefit from the performance improvement of using async zk api. So, instead of patching these jiras individually, I am wondering if we should step back a bit and think about the long term plan. For example, should we just remove the dependency on zkclient and use the raw ZK client directly?

@bondj the change seems sensible to me, it avoids printing the error messages with the stack trace. I'm not sure why you're being flooded with those messages in your log. If the producer reconnects, then shouldn't it produce another error only x minutes later, for whatever timeout you have? I'm trying to understand if this fully solves the problem you're reporting.

@junrao Yes, I agree that in long term we should probably use raw ZK client. Eventually we will have our own wrapper ZK client around the raw ZK client. 

We can either have a big patch that replace all the current ZK usage with our wrapper client based on raw ZK Client in one shot, or we can do it gradually in multiple patches. In this patch, I am taking the second approach, it seems a reasonable and relatively smooth way for migration. And I think it also solves KAFKA-3083.

In this patch I introduced our own wrapper client. It is currently extending the org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient. So that we can get the protected raw ZK client in side it. That means we are essentially dealing with a raw ZK client in our own wrapper when we do async read and write. I noticed that actually Apache Helix is using this similar approach.

The good things about this approach are that:
1. There is no duplicate efforts compared with the final state. We are essentially writing our own ZK wrapper around raw ZK Client. We will add more and more methods to our own wrapper to replace the methods in org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient.
2. We don't need to introduce two ZK client at the same time.
3. It is low risk and more smooth for migration. We can add more and more methods in our ZK client wrapper based on the raw ZK client. Once we no longer call any methods from org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient, we remove it from Kafka completely.

That said, I am also fine if we want to have a big patch to replace everything in one shot.

@becketqin I was thinking of an approach in which we don't change the signatures of methods in `ZkUtils` but reimplement them to use async calls directly to the raw zk handle. One advantage is that we don't have to make changes anywhere else with respect to zk. One problem is that we can't solve problems like the one of this issue until we rewire and then start adding methods, changing signatures, etc.

The main issue I see with ZkClient currently is the automatic session creation, which will require some work. That's the main reason I wanted to focus on that first before we make async calls available. But clearly it depends on how much we delay the two speed-up issues currently open, this one and KAFKA-3038. Otherwise, the approach here seems fine at a high-level. I can review it more thoroughly if we agree that now is the time to do it, I suppose it depends on how pressing this is for you.
Test unrelated to this PR failed. Closing and reopening.
Tests passed locally. Re-opening.

@fpj Thanks for the comments. Reworking the zkUtils would be great. It is just in that case we probably still need to handle all the re-connection by ourselves. Which might have some similar logic as ZKClient is currently doing. 

After taking a closer look at the ZkClient code and our code, I feel exactly the same thing as you mentioned: zkClient is a convenient client except it re-connects **_silently**_ on session expiration / disconnection. I am trying to see if we can work around this issue but still keep the useful features which are something we probably also have to write even if we use raw ZK client, e.g re-connect, listeners, etc.

That is why I added this `withCurrentSession` method to zkUtils which guarantees us some session-bound state when we update ZK paths. The current PR only uses it for asynchronous ZK path update, but it is pretty trivial to also use it for synchronous updates as well. 

I think this is a simple and quick solution to the issues we have seen so far, KAFKA-3083, KAFKA-3038 as well as this ticket. Most importantly, this patch does not introduce any duplicate work to KAFKA-3210. All the rework in zkUtils can still be done. It will give us the freedom to either continue to add more methods to our own ZK clients without blocking anything or we can re-evaluate and see whether that is still needed.
@Ishiihara I had a couple minor questions, but this seems reasonable to me. It would be nice and hopefully not too much trouble if you could add a unit test.

This PR seems to cause issues to the Gradle import of IntelliJ 2016.1.1. References to test classes are marked as red. If I revert to the commit before this and I re-import then things work fine. Anyone one else tested this?
@ijuma I tested it with Intellij 15.0.3 and had no issues. I will update my Intellij and report back.
@ijuma I didn't have any issues. You could try refreshing the gradle project, file -> synchronize, or file -> invalidate caches.
@granthenke I did both before asking the question. I'll try a clean checkout as well. You checked test files, yes?

@becketqin here are some more thoughts:

> It is just in that case we probably still need to handle all the re-connection by ourselves.

Yep, that's precisely what we need to do, we shouldn't be re-creating sessions transparently.

> Which might have some similar logic as ZKClient is currently doing.

I'm not super clear about it. Here are a few points:
- We need a mechanism to inform all parts of the code that need to know about it, listeners make sense although we need to be careful with the order of delivery. The zookeeper client guarantees order, I can't remember now if ZkClient respects it, although if I recall correctly, they use a separate thread to deliver events.
- We need to make sure to fail all pending operations rather than transparently create a new session and retry. This is fairly different from how ZkClient does it today.
- When a session expires, we need to create a new session for liveness, unless we decide to shutdown the broker and restart it with a watchdog or manually, which I'm under the impression we don't want to do. However, we can only re-create the session once we are sure that no operation is going to spill from the old session to the next. We need to block the session creation until we have confirmation from the broker that we can proceed. This is fairly different as well.
- I'd like to support the asynchronous api because it gives us a speed advantage, and ZkClient doesn't currently support it as you have observed. ZkClient could be changed to support the asynchronous api, but it would require a few changes.

> That is why I added this withCurrentSession method to zkUtils which guarantees us some session-bound state when we update ZK paths.

Sounds like a good thing to do, but it doesn't completely get rid of races. I can start a zk request at the exact moment I create a new session, so logically I'm in the old session but the request will be executed in the new because the current session is the latest one created. 

> this patch does not introduce any duplicate work to KAFKA-3210

It duplicates in the sense that we were proposing to introduce asynchronous api in a systematic manner rather than sprinkle it across the code. Our concern is that it could become even harder to manage the interaction with zookeeper if we start using different approaches across the code.

Let me have a closer look at your proposal and get back to you, I want to think a bit more about your proposal and its impact longer term.
@fpj maybe you could take a look

@ijuma It looks like this is a regression in Intellij that is exposed when 2 modules point to the same source. It is tracked by [IDEA-154014](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-154014), [IDEA-153264](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-153264), and [IDEA-153231](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-153231). 

It can be worked around by going to `File -> Project Structure -> Modules` and removing the `core_scoverage` and `core_testScoverage` modules.

@granthenke Thanks for the PR -  the overall organization is looking great! 
Just a few observations:
- like `kafka_test.py`, `produce_consume_validate.py` is shared by multiple tests, so it probably doesn't belong under client - you can probably restore to its original location.
- there are some broken import statements caused by the shuffle - restoring `produce_consume_validate.py` to original location will probably be enough

One way to check that you're on the right track is to list the tests picked up by test discovery mechanism in both trunk and your branch. A necessary condition for success is that the collection of tests picked up should match between branches:

```
cd kafka
ducktape tests/ --collect-only  # compare (apache/kafka) trunk vs your branch

# you may want to clean out .pyc files etc when you move stuff around:
# find . | grep -E "(__pycache__|\.pyc$)" | xargs rm -rf
```

When I try this in your branch, I only pick up 62 tests out of ~160. This is most likely caused the broken imports I mentioned.

Once imports are fixed, we can run the tests in branch builder to make sure that tests can still pick up the templates they need. The layout looks right, but it will be good to validate this.

LGTM, cc @gwenshap.
LGTM!

@granthenke Yeah, that was what I was getting at -- it seems like the only way to make the test pass reliably with its current structure. I'm open to other approaches too, I just felt like changing the number and hoping that's good enough to avoid hitting the max # of retries seemed like an unreliable solution (but perhaps perfectly fine temporary stopgap).
I would prefer a configurable retry number too, personally.

@fpj Thanks for the detailed explanation. I think we are totally on the same page and I believe this patch follows exactly what you suggested.

The async write / read directly uses the raw ZooKeeper client. It does not depend on any ZkClient functions. The only difference is that instead of creating a separate raw ZooKeeper client, it use the ZooKeeper client wrapped inside ZkClient. This is necessary because we don't want to have two ZooKeeper connections. This patch is actually surprisingly small (I pasted later).

> Sounds like a good thing to do, but it doesn't completely get rid of races. I can start a zk request at the exact moment I create a new session, so logically I'm in the old session but the request will be executed in the new because the current session is the latest one created.

The way withCurrentSession works is:
1. cache the current raw ZooKeeper object.
2. check if the pre-condition is met (e.g. is this broker still controller)
3. use the cached ZooKeeper object taken in step 1 to perform the ZooKeeper update.
ZkClient might re-create the session at any point.
If re-connection / expiration happened before step 1, the update should not see any exception.
If re-connection / expiration happened after step 1, step 3 will see exception, because the cached ZooKeeper object has already disconnected from the server or its session has already expired. In this case, we propagate the exception to the upper layer to handle. (In this patch, the upper layer will retry the operation with the new session. The pre-condition will be checked again on the new session, of course.
Not sure if I missed something, but it seems in any case we will not silently use a newly re-created connection without validating the pre-condition on that connection.

```
  // With current session
  def withCurrentSession(preconditionChecker: Option[() => Boolean] = None)(f: ZooKeeper => Unit) {
    val currentZk = zkClient.currentZk
    if (!preconditionChecker.fold(true)(f => f()))
      throw new IllegalStateException("The pre-check failed.")
    f(currentZk)
  }
```

> We need a mechanism to inform all parts of the code that need to know about it, listeners make sense although we need to be careful with the order of delivery. The zookeeper client guarantees order, I can't remember now if ZkClient respects it, although if I recall correctly, they use a separate thread to deliver events.
> When a session expires, we need to create a new session for liveness, unless we decide to shutdown the broker and restart it with a watchdog or manually, which I'm under the impression we don't want to do. However, we can only re-create the session once we are sure that no operation is going to spill from the old session to the next. We need to block the session creation until we have confirmation from the broker that we can proceed. This is fairly different as well.
> We need to make sure to fail all pending operations rather than transparently create a new session and retry. This is fairly different from how ZkClient does it today.

Although ZkClient can recreate session transparently, as mentioned in `withCurrentSession`,  we will not silently use the re-created session without validating the pre-condition on that session. Exception will be propagated to let the upper layer to handle in that case. So it looks we don't need to worry about ZkClient implementation. 

> It duplicates in the sense that we were proposing to introduce asynchronous api in a systematic manner rather than sprinkle it across the code. Our concern is that it could become even harder to manage the interaction with zookeeper if we start using different approaches across the code.

The async writes and reads introduced in this patch is intended for general ZooKeeper read / write purpose directly depends on raw ZooKeeper client. In fact this part of the code are literally 30 lines. These code can be used to replace all the current zookeeper usage across the board.

```
  private[kafka] class ZkClient(zkConnection: IZkConnection, connectionTimeout: Int, zkSerializer: ZkSerializer)
  extends org.I0Itec.zkclient.ZkClient(zkConnection, connectionTimeout, zkSerializer) {

  def asyncWriteDataAndReturnStat(path: String,
                                  datat: String,
                                  callbackWithData: StatCallback,
                                  expectedVersion: Int,
                                  zkOpt: Option[ZooKeeper] = None) = {
    val data: Array[Byte] = ZKStringSerializer.serialize(datat)
    var zk = zkOpt.getOrElse(currentZk)
    zk.setData(path, data, expectedVersion, callbackWithData, null)
  }

  def asyncReadData(path: String, callback: DataCallback) {
    retryUntilConnected(new Callable[Object] {
      def call: Object = {
        currentZk.getData(path, false, callback, null)
        null
      }
    })
  }

  def currentZk = _connection.asInstanceOf[ZkConnection].getZookeeper
}
```

I don't have a strong opinion on whether we should replace all the zk read / write with asynch version in one shot or not. That is not a bad idea. 
At a high level, there are two jobs needs to be done:
1. Introduce the async ZK read / write primitives that does not naively use a new session silently.
2. Use the primitives in (1) to replace the current ZK usage.

We can 
**a)** do both (1) and (2) in one patch; or 
**b)** do (1) in a patch then (2) in another patch; or 
**c)** do (1) in one patch and (2) in several patches. 
This patch is taking approach **c)**. It did (1) and a part of (2), and will migrate other ZK usages to use async ZK read / write in other patches.
So this patch does not seem to be duplicate efforts compared to the end state. It is just walking at a different pace.
*_The real question to be answered for this patch is that whether the above code snippet solves our concern with ZkClient or not. *_
If it does, I think this patch gives us the freedom either continuing developing based on raw ZooKeeper client or just leave it as it is until we see compelling reason to do that.

I don't oppose to take approach **a)** in this patch if people think it is better, although personally I don't see much value to re-write the other functions in ZkClient which we don't have problem with.

I'm very sorry to run you around, but I thought about it a bit more:
Users of GetOffset currently don't know that it is using a producer (since we are using it internally for a very accidental method), so having --old-producer configuration will just confuse everyone.

Lets just get rid of the use of old producer completely. We will still be consistent since this tool hides the use of producer from the user...

Took another look, I think I misunderstood the high watermark. It's the first offset past the most recently committed offset, not the most recently committed offset. I've reverted the changes except throwing OffsetOutOfRange when requesting a message past maxOffset.

@matthewlmcclure Changes seem fine, could you fix the PR title to match the guidelines here: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes ?

Also, do we think this is the only conformance issue? There are a bunch of other bin scripts that assume `bash`. I'm not convinced that standardizing on bash wouldn't be better since everyone seems to assume it -- any new scripts or modifications to existing scripts are at risk of making the same mistakes.

Test run looks good (there was a transient failure, but number of tests is fine), reorg looks mostly good to me. @granthenke is there a reason things like `consumer_group_command_test.py` and `get_offset_shell_test.py` should be under `core` instead of `tools`? Not sure exactly how you wanted to break these down, but `core` struck me as being the name for core broker tests, whereas tools would cover things like CLI tools. Something like MM is a case where I'm not sure where it should live...

But otherwise, this LGTM

This is already being handled in #1148, maybe.

@ewencp My intent was to match the module structure. The log4-appender tests use VerifiableLog4jAppender which is in the tools module. The other pieces under tools are shared among the tests so I did not put them in the tools folder.
@granthenke Oh, duh, my bad for missing that. In that case, LGTM.

@hachikuji Can you take a look at my initial attempt to reduce unsent requests? This is the simplest solution I could come up with, but I am not sure if I have missed something. Rather than clearing unsent requests for every `ConsumerNetworkClient.poll`, the PR fails unsent requests only when returning from `KafkaConsumer.poll` after the loop of `ConsumerNetworkClient.poll`s. It fixes the problem with failures during handshake, but I wasn't sure if there was a reason why unsent requests had to be cleared on every iteration.
For trivial fixes like this, it's fine to include in other PRs like #1180 by the way.
Thanks @ijuma. Done.
Tests passed locally.
@gwenshap, @ijuma addressed your concerns. Mind giving it another pass. Thanks!
@rajinisivaram At a glance, the approach seems interesting. I'll look more carefully this afternoon.

@gwenshap that is a good point, but this raises a question that should it be hidden. To use new producer against a secure Kafka installation, user will have to specify security configs in producer.config file. Irrespective of whether we want to hide producer from user or not, another question is that if it is OK to remove old producer from one tool while keeping it in other tools? Maybe we should keep it around till we completely remove old-producer? If you still think old-producer is not worth keeping around in this tool, I will update the PR.
